Selected Answer: D
The answer is letter D, answers A and B are clearly wrong, C would also be right, but what shows that it is wrong is the code fragment that calls the class directly. You cannot instantiate abstract classes directly as it was done in the code snippet, so the letter D is correct, implement the abstracted method.

Selected Answer: C
Example A:
String a = "hello" + " world!"; String b = "hello world!"; boolean compare = (a == b); // This return true
Example B:
a = "hello"; b = "hel" + "lo"; compare = (a == b); // This return true
Example C:
a = "Bye"; a += " bye!"; b = "Bye bye!"; compare = (a == b); // This return false


System.out.println(compare);

Selected Answer: C
Correct is C, when the equals method is called, the content stored inside the String is analyzed. When the "==" is put it will always give false in case of Strings, because it is not of the primitive type.
